title: 108_hr3579
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Credit Union Regulatory Improvements Act of 2003". It includes provisions for leasing land on federal facilities for credit unions. The Federal Credit Union Act is amended to allow credit unions to lease land on federal facilities. The heading for section 124 is updated to include "or federal land" after "buildings". SEC. 103. INVESTMENTS IN SECURITIES BY FEDERAL CREDIT UNIONS. Section 107 of the Federal Credit Union Act is amended to allow Federal credit unions to purchase and hold investment securities for their own account, subject to regulations and limitations set by the Board. Federal credit unions can hold investment securities for their own account, with limitations set by the Board. The securities must not exceed 10 percent of the credit union's net worth or assets. Investment securities are defined as marketable obligations like bonds, notes, or debentures. The Board may further define investment securities as instruments commonly referred to as investment securities. Investment grade means an investment security rated in the top four categories by a recognized rating organization. Federal credit unions are prohibited from purchasing stock for their own account. SEC. 104. INCREASE IN GENERAL 12-YEAR LIMITATION OF TERM OF FEDERAL CREDIT UNION LOANS TO 15 YEARS. Section 107(a)(5) of the Federal Credit Union Act is amended to allow for loan maturities of up to 15 years or longer as determined by the Board in regulations. Subparagraph (A) is revised by removing clause (ii) and renumbering clauses (iii) through (x). SEC. 105 increases the investment limit in credit union service organizations from 1% to 3% of the total paid. SEC. 106 excludes loans made to nonprofit religious organizations from the member business loan exclusion. SEC. 107 allows for check cashing and money transfer services within the field of membership. SEC. 107 of the Federal Credit Union Act allows credit unions to provide check cashing, money transfer services, and electronic fund transfers within their field of membership, subject to regulations prescribed by the Board. SEC. 108 allows for voluntary mergers involving multiple common-bond credit unions, with specific amendments to the Federal Credit Union Act. Section 109(g) of the Federal Credit Union Act is amended to include criteria for continued membership in community charter conversions. The Board will determine if member groups outside the defined community can still be served by the credit union. The Federal Credit Union Act allows for the expulsion of members for just cause, such as nonparticipation or disruption of credit union operations. The board of directors can adopt a policy for expulsion by majority vote, with written notice provided to members. The Federal Credit Union Act allows for the adoption of a policy on term limits for board members and reimbursement for lost wages. Existing members must be notified 30 days before the policy takes effect, while new members must be informed upon applying for membership. The Federal Credit Union Act allows for a policy on term limits for board members and reimbursement of lost wages and reasonable expenses. SEC. 111 amends the Federal Credit Union Act for greater flexibility in responding to market conditions. SEC. 112 allows credit unions to lease space in buildings in underserved areas. SEC. 111 of the Federal Credit Union Act allows credit unions to lease office space in buildings purchased or constructed for credit union operations in underserved areas to business enterprises, subject to regulations for safety and soundness. The term 'underserved area' in the Federal Credit Union Act is defined as an area with a poverty rate of 20% or greater, or a median family income below 80% of the area or state median income. SEC. 113 amends voting requirements for credit union conversions, requiring at least 20% membership participation. SEC. 114 exempts credit unions from pre-merger notification requirements of the Clayton Act. SEC. 115 addresses the treatment of credit unions as depository institutions under securities laws. Definition of Bank under Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to include insured credit unions and receivers. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to include insured credit unions and receivers. The definition of Appropriate Federal Banking Agency is expanded to include the National Credit Union Administration Board for insured credit unions. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to include insured credit unions and receivers, expanding the definition of Appropriate Federal Banking Agency to include the National Credit Union Administration Board for insured credit unions. TITLE II--MEMBER BUSINESS LENDING

SEC. 201. LIMITS ON MEMBER BUSINESS LOANS: Amends the Federal Credit Union Act to set the limit on member business loans at 20 percent of the total assets of the credit union.

SEC. 202. DEFINITION OF MEMBER BUSINESS LOAN: Amends the Act to allow for member business loans up to $100,000 as prescribed by the Board.

SEC. 203. RESTRICTION ON MEMBER BUSINESS LOANS: Amends the Act to require Board approval for member business loans.

TITLE III--CAPITAL LEVELS

SEC. 301. AMENDMENTS TO NET WORTH CATEGORIES: Makes amendments to net worth categories. Section 216 of the Federal Credit Union Act is amended to define the net worth ratio and criteria for a credit union to be considered critically undercapitalized. The net worth ratio for a credit union to be considered critically undercapitalized is defined as a minimum of 2 percent but not more than 3 percent.
